item.title: Cancer care as electoral commitment
item.description: Cancer is no longer a medical condition. It is a long and painful struggle of thousands of families, a cause of financial ruin and a sign of unequal access to health care. In Bangladesh, about 300,000 people are diagnosed with cancer every year and nearly 150,000 die. The numbers continue to increase, showing that cancer has become a serious national public health crisis......

item.title: Power, patronage and popular perceptions
item.description: OVER the past few weeks, a series of discourse and debates has emerged around the idea that the United States is seeking to draw closer to Jamaat-e-Islami of Bangladesh, framing this as a new or sudden diplomatic shift. This reading, however, risks overlooking a longer and more complicated history. Without casting these engagements as inherently good or bad, it is......

item.title: What lies behind the mask?
item.description: Bangladesh stands today at a decisive crossroads in its journey toward democratic transformation. The upcoming national parliamentary election is far from an ordinary contest for state power; it will shape the country’s political trajectory for years to come. Elections are often regarded as the ultimate expression of citizens’ sovereign will to choose their representatives......

item.title: Last-minute ordinances, lost reforms
